case_name: V. K. A. Ranganatha Konar v. Tiruchirappalli Municipal Council

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 675 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 17, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 92 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 675 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 17, 1960 of the Madras High Court in Appeal Suit No. 92 of 1957. V. R. Tatachari, for the appella

facts.text: On September 1, 1944, respondent No. 1, Tiruchirappalli Municipal Council, leased T.S. No. 3283/1-A/2 to the appellant, V. K. A. Ranganatha Konar, for a term of three years at a rent of Rs. 100/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1, 1944, respondent No. 1, Tiruchirappalli Municipal Council, leased T.S. No. 3283/1-A/2 to the appellant, V. K. A. Ranganatha Konar, for a term of three years at a rent of Rs. 100/- per month.

facts.text: The appellant erected a building on the premises for the purpose of exhibiting cinematographic films.

anchor.surface_text: On the premises thus let out to him, the appellant erected a building for the purpose of exhibiting cinematographic films. In 1945, he sub-leased the property to the second respondent, A. Muthukumaran.

facts.text: In 1945, the appellant sub-leased the property to the second respondent, A. Muthukumaran.

anchor.surface_text: In 1945, he sub-leased the property to the second respondent, A. Muthukumaran. In 1947, the lease was renewed for a period of three years, and so, it expired on March 31, 1950.

facts.text: In 1947, the lease was renewed for a period of three years, expiring on March 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947, the lease was renewed for a period of three years, and so, it expired on March 31, 1950. Nevertheless, the appellant and respondent No. 2 continued in possession.

facts.text: The lease expired on March 31, 1950, but the appellant and respondent No. 2 continued in possession.

anchor.surface_text: Nevertheless, the appellant and respondent No. 2 continued in possession. On December 23, 1954, respondent No. 1 instituted a suit for the eviction of the appellant and respondent No. 2 and for arrears of rent.

facts.text: On December 23, 1954, respondent No. 1 instituted a suit for the eviction of the appellant and respondent No. 2 and for arrears of rent.

anchor.surface_text: On December 23, 1954, respondent No. 1 instituted a suit for the eviction of the appellant and respondent No. 2 and for arrears of rent. While the suit was pending the Act was extended to the Municipal Town of Tiruchirappalli.

facts.text: While the suit was pending, the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921 was extended to the Municipal Town of Tiruchirappalli.

anchor.surface_text: While the suit was pending the Act was extended to the Municipal Town of Tiruchirappalli. Accordingly, the value of the improvements made by the appellant and respondent No. 2 was determined by the learned trial Judge

facts.text: The value of the improvements made by the appellant and respondent No. 2 was determined by the trial Judge to be Rs. 64,661-13-5 under s. 4(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the value of the improvements made by the appellant and respondent No. 2 was determined by the learned trial Judge and declared to be Rs. 64,661-13-5 under s. 4(1) of the Act.

facts.text: On March 26, 1956, the trial Court passed a decree providing that the defendants put the plaintiff in possession on payment of Rs. 64,661-13-5 by the plaintiff to the first defendant, without directing payment within three months.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1956, the trial Court passed a decree which, inter alia, provided that the defendants do put the plaintiff in possession of the suit properties described hereunder on payment of Rs. 64,661-13-5 by the plaintiff to the first defendant

facts.text: The appellant was the first defendant in the trial court proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: being the compensation for the superstructure belonging to the first defendant. The appellant was the first defendant in the said proceedings.

facts.text: On October 1, 1956, the appellant filed I.A. No. 301 of 1956 claiming dismissal of the suit under s. 4(4) as no deposit was made within three months.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1956, the appellant filed an application I.A. No. 301 of 1956 inviting the attention of the Court to the fact that respondent No. 1 had not made the deposit within three months from the date of the decree,

facts.text: On November 5, 1956, respondent No. 1 filed a counter to the appellant's application and another interlocutory application to amend the decree to specify the time for deposit.

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1956, respondent No. 1 filed a counter to this interlocutory application. On the same date, respondent No. 1. filed another interlocutory application praying that the decree in question should be amended

facts.text: On November 15, 1956, respondent No. 1 sent a cheque to the Court for the amount, which was cashed on November 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Pending these applications, on November 15. 1956, respondent No. 1 sent a cheque to the Court in regard to the said amount .The said cheque was duly cashed and the amount credited in the accounts of the Court on November 20, 1956.

facts.text: The trial Judge ordered amendment of the decree to direct deposit before June 23, 1956, but then dismissed the suit under s. 4(4).

anchor.surface_text: On the date the trial Judge passed an order directing that the decree should be amended by inserting a direction to the effect that the deposit should be made before June 23, 1956, that is to say within three months from March 26, 1956

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed the dismissal to the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Since this amendment could not help respondent No. 1, the learned trial Judge proceeded to pass an order dismissing the suit under the provisions of s. 4(4) This order of dismissal was challenged by respondent No. 1 by an appeal

facts.text: The Madras High Court allowed respondent No. 1's appeal, confirmed the original decree of March 26, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In substance, the High Court has accepted this plea, with the result that the appeal preferred by respondent No. 1 has been allowed and the original decree passed on March 26, 1956, has been confirmed.

facts.text: The appellant obtained a certificate from the High Court and filed this appeal before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The result of this decision is that respondent No. 1 is at liberty to take out execution for obtaining possession of the property. The appellant then applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court

facts.text: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the High Court decree, and restored the trial court's order dismissing the suit under s. 4(4).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that the High Court was in error in reversing the order passed by the trial Court. Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4) . The result is, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the trial Court restored.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 did not pay the amount within three months from the date of the decree.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4) .

facts.text: The Act was passed in 1922 as Madras Act III of 1922.

anchor.surface_text: of S. 4(1) read with S. 4(4) of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921 (Madras Act III of 1922) hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: The Act was extended to the municipal area of Tiruchirappalli while the suit was pending in the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: While the suit was pending the Act was extended to the Municipal Town of Tiruchirappalli while the present suit between the parties was pending in the trial Court.

facts.text: V. R. Tatachari appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: V. R. Tatachari, for the appellant. V. Viswanatha Sastri and S. Venkatakrishnan, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: V. Viswanatha Sastri and S. Venkatakrishnan appeared for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: V. Viswanatha Sastri and S. Venkatakrishnan, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C.J.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Gajendragadkar, C.J. The short question which this appeal raises before us relates to the construction

the companystruction of S. 4 1  read with S. 4  4  of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921  Madras Act III of 1922   hereinafter called the Act . This question arises in this way. On September 1, 1944, respondent No. 1, Tiruchirappalli Municipal Council, leased T.S. No. 3283/1-A/2 to the appellant, V. K. A. Ranganatha Konar, for a term of three years at a rent of Rs. 100/- per month.

concepts.interpretation: Decree must declare compensation amount and direct possession on payment into court within three months; the payment clause is a condition, not a strict form requirement controlling S.4(4); defective form does not exempt application of S.4(4).

concepts.unlisted_description: Requires court in ejectment suit to ascertain compensation and decree possession conditional on landlord's payment within 3 months.

Ranganatha Konar, for a term of three years at a rent of Rs. 100/- per month.

concepts.interpretation: Mandatory provision; if compensation not paid within 3 months from decree date under S.4(1), suit stands dismissed; applies even to decrees not expressly specifying the 3-month period.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: under s. 4 1  specifying the period of three months within which the amount should be paid, and then s. 4 4  can be invoked. That is how Mr. Sastri h

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4(4) Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921
concepts.unlisted_description: Automatic dismissal of ejectment suit if compensation not deposited within 3 months.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the value of the improvements made by the appellant and respondent No. 2 was determined by the learned trial Judge and declared to be Rs. 64,661-13-5 under s. 4 1  of the Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3 Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921
concepts.unlisted_description: Deals with determination of compensation for buildings constructed by tenant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the logical way to reconcile S. 4 1  and S. 4 4  would be to treat the provision prescribed by s. 4 4  as mandatory and paramount and read the relevant portion of s. 4 1  accordingly. That is why even if the decree does number mention that the amount has to be paid within three months, the landlords obligation to make the payment within three months is still enforceable under s. 4 4 , otherwise defective decrees would deprive the tenants of the benefit intended to be companyferred on them by s. 4 4 .

concepts.interpretation: S.4(1) read with S.4(4) by treating S.4(4) as paramount and mandatory, so that defective decrees under S.4(1) do not defeat tenant protection under S.4(4).

concepts.interpretation: Applies Act protections including S.4 to pending ejectment suits upon extension of Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  deals with cases in which decrees for ejectment have been passed, but the amount of companypensation has number been determined, and it provides that on an application by the tenant, such amount would be determined in accordance with s. 4.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 3  deals with cases of decrees which are pending execution and it requires that the Court shall, on the application of the tenant, recall execution orders, ascertain the amount of companypensation, and pass an interim order under s. 4.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10(3) Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921
concepts.unlisted_description: Recall of execution and compensation ascertainment for pending executions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri for respondent No. 1 has strenuously companytended that in appreciating the effect of the two relevant provisions, it is necessary to bear in mind that ultimately, the direction companytained in the decree must be enforced, and if the original decree did number require respondent No. 1 to pay the companypensation amount within three months, the right of the appellant to recover that amount must inevitably be enforced by execution proceedings under Article 182 of the Limitation Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Limitation period for execution of decrees.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 1  provides that sections 4, 5, 6, 8, 9 and 9-A shall, inter alia, apply to suits in ejectment which are pending or in which decrees for ejectment have been passed, but have number been executed.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with this question, it is necessary to bear in mind the object which the Act is intended to achieve. As the preamble indicates, the Act was passed to give protection to certain classes of tenants in areas to which it was extended. The Legislature thought that it was necessary to give protection to tenants who had companystructed buildings on others lands in the hope that they would number be evicted so long as they paid a fair rent for the land.

concepts.interpretation: Statutory protection against eviction for tenants who built structures on leased land upon paying fair rent and compensation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: nt, the Court shall ascertain the amount of companypensation payable to the tenant, and the decree in the suit shall declare the amount so found due a

concepts.unlisted_description: Legislative policy to protect tenants' investments in superstructures.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that the High Court was in error in reversing the order passed by the trial Court. Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4) .

holdings.text: The logical way to reconcile S. 4(1) and S. 4(4) would be to treat the provision prescribed by s. 4(4) as mandatory and paramount and read the relevant portion of s. 4(1) accordingly. That is why even if the decree does not mention that the amount has to be paid within three months, the landlord's obligation to make the payment within three months is still enforceable under s. 4(4).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the logical way to reconcile S. 4 1  and S. 4  4  would be to treat the provision prescribed by s. 4 4  as mandatory and paramount and read the relevant portion of s. 4 1  accordingly. That is why even if the decree does number mention that the amount has to be paid within three months, the landlords obligation to make the payment within three months is still enforceable under s. 4 4 , otherwise defective decrees would deprive the tenants of the benefit intended to be companyferred on them by s. 4 4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction prioritizes mandatory tenant protection in s.4(4) over formal defects in s.4(1) decrees to prevent circumvention of legislative intent.

holdings.text: The applicability of s. 4(4) cannot be repelled merely on the ground that the decree passed under s. 4(1) does not specify the period of three months within which the amount found due has to be paid.

anchor.surface_text: The applicability of s. 4 4  cannot be repelled merely on the ground that the decree passed under 6. 4  1   does number specify the period of three months within which the amount found due has to be paid. In our opinion, the logical way to reconcile S. 4 1  and S. 4  4  would be to treat the provision prescribed by s. 4 4  as mandatory and paramount

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defective form in decree does not exempt s.4(4); emphasis on decree date and mandatory dismissal for non-payment.

holdings.text: The reference to payment by the landlord within three months in s. 4(1) amounts to a condition which has to be satisfied, not a direction issued by the Court controlling s. 4(4).

anchor.surface_text: The clause in respect of the payment by the landlord into companyrt within three months amounts to a companydition which has to be satisfied by the landlord before the tenant is required to deliver to him possession of the property in question. In other words, reference to the payment by the landlord of the amount found due within the specified period in s. 4 1  is number so much a direction issued by the Court as specification of a companydition expressly and independently provided by s. 4 4 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) payment clause is conditional language tied to independent mandatory s.4(4); not form-controlling.

holdings.text: The expression 'the decree under sub-section (1)' merely describes the sub-section under which the decree is passed, with emphasis on the date of the decree rather than strict compliance with the form of s. 4(1).

anchor.surface_text: The opening clause of s. 4 4  shows that the amount has to be paid within three months from the date of the decree passed under sub-section  1 . The expression the decree under sub-section   1   merely describes the sub-section under which the decree is passed, the emphasis in the companytext being on the date of the said decree and number so much on the strict companypliance with the form prescribed by s. 4 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language focuses on substantive decree date for triggering s.4(4) limitation, not verbatim form.

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4).

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4) .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show deposit after June 23, 1956; mandatory s.4(4) applies directly.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in reversing the trial Court's order; the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the trial Court restored.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore satisfied that the High Court was in error in reversing the order passed by the trial Court. Respondent No. 1 has not paid the amount within three months from the date of the decree and the suit instituted by it shall stand dismissed under s. 4(4) . The result is, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the trial Court restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct application of interpreted ss.4(1)/(4) to facts warrants restoration of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the trial Court restored.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; decree of the High Court set aside; decree of the trial court restored (dismissing the respondent No. 1's suit under s. 4(4) of the Act).
